hints_html: Use antidifferentiation of the power rule to find f. Don’t forget your constants.
hints_latex:
Use antidifferentiation of the power rule to find \emph{f}. Don't forget
your constants.
hints_raw: Use antidifferentiation of the power rule to find ''f''. Don't forget your constants.
question: 1 (n)
sols_html:
If \(\displaystyle f''(t) = \frac{3}{\sqrt{t}}\), then antidifferentiating gives

\(\displaystyle f'(t) = 6\sqrt{t} + C\). Since \(\displaystyle f'(4) = 7\), we have that

\(\displaystyle 7 = f'(4) = 6\sqrt{4} + C = 12 + C\)

and hence C=-5. Thus

\(\displaystyle f'(t) = 6\sqrt{t} -5\)

and antidifferentiating once more gives

\(\displaystyle f(t) = 4\sqrt{t}^{3} -5t + D\)

Since \(\displaystyle f(4) = 2\), we see that

\(\displaystyle 2 = f(4) = 4\sqrt{4}^{3} -5(4) + D = 12 + D\)

and so D=-10. Thus, the function we seek is

\(\displaystyle f(t) = 4\sqrt{t}^{3} -5t - 10\)
sols_latex:
If $\displaystyle f''(t) = \frac{3}{\sqrt{t}}$, then antidifferentiating
gives

$\displaystyle f'(t) = 6\sqrt{t} + C$. Since $\displaystyle f'(4) = 7$,
we have that

$\displaystyle 7 = f'(4) = 6\sqrt{4} + C = 12 + C$

and hence \emph{C}=-5. Thus

$\displaystyle f'(t) = 6\sqrt{t} -5$

and antidifferentiating once more gives

$\displaystyle f(t) = 4\sqrt{t}^{3} -5t + D$

Since $\displaystyle f(4) = 2$, we see that

$\displaystyle 2 = f(4) = 4\sqrt{4}^{3} -5(4) + D = 12 + D$

and so \emph{D}=-10. Thus, the function we seek is

$\displaystyle f(t) = 4\sqrt{t}^{3} -5t - 10$
sols_raw:
If <math> \displaystyle f''(t) = \frac{3}{\sqrt{t}} </math>, then antidifferentiating gives 

<math> \displaystyle f'(t) = 6\sqrt{t} + C </math>. Since <math> \displaystyle f'(4) = 7 </math>, we have that

<math> \displaystyle 7 = f'(4) = 6\sqrt{4} + C = 12 + C </math>

and hence ''C''=-5. Thus

<math> \displaystyle f'(t) = 6\sqrt{t} -5 </math>

and antidifferentiating once more gives

<math> \displaystyle f(t) = 4\sqrt{t}^{3} -5t + D </math>

Since <math> \displaystyle f(4) = 2 </math>, we see that 

<math> \displaystyle 2 = f(4) = 4\sqrt{4}^{3} -5(4) + D = 12 + D </math>

and so ''D''=-10. Thus, the function we seek is 

<math> \displaystyle f(t) = 4\sqrt{t}^{3} -5t - 10 </math>
statement_html: Find \(\displaystyle f(t)\), if \(\displaystyle f''(t) = \frac{3}{\sqrt{t}}\), \(\displaystyle f(4) = 2\) and \(\displaystyle f'(4) = 7\)
statement_latex:
Find $\displaystyle f(t)$, if
$\displaystyle f''(t) = \frac{3}{\sqrt{t}}$, $\displaystyle f(4) = 2$
and $\displaystyle f'(4) = 7$
statement_raw: Find <math> \displaystyle f(t) </math>, if <math> \displaystyle f''(t) = \frac{3}{\sqrt{t}} </math>, <math> \displaystyle f(4) = 2 </math> and <math> \displaystyle f'(4) = 7 </math>
